I didn’t realize (who would?!) that there’s a small cottage industry around visualizing bluesy Brit bands as family trees — a rump monarchist tendency, I guess? 😹. I was more of a psychedelic punk, so I don’t have a dog in this hunt; but there’s lots to learn from liminal / ephemeral stuff that’s relevant to #dataviz and everything it touches. A few things of note:

(1) Parochial tendencies: In this example, John Mayall’s Bluesbreakers #5 (row 4, center) includes John McVie, but apparently Fleetwood Mac doesn’t make the cut? Surprising because, AFAIK (not too far, granted), they were pretty insular and had a stable crew, so fitting them in wouldn’t have been hard. The exception to that stability: Stevie Nicks, who had a huge indy career. So cutting off FM might have less to do with that band’s significance than with the wormhole it opens up: successful women artists (cc @kanarinka). No surprise if that hints at sexist tendencies. Not too surprising given hypermasculine context; or maybe it was “just” an anti-pop/rock bias.

(2) Most of these images are *very* analog: Not so interesting in itself, but *contextually* it’s a useful counterexample to the software-defined aesthetic of the most current #dataviz. It didn’t have to be so, and current practitioners would learn lots from looking at pre-automated examples. There were many, but (a) not only were they not canonized in the Church of Tufte but they were ideologically excluded in his work as “junk”; and (b) they run counter to the lionization of 19th- and early 20th-C figures.

(3) “Dataviz” itself is a hyperideological framing, bc it accepts (and imposes) all kinds of normy technocratic ideas about history: what’s in/admissible, what forms facts can / must take, how they’re ~processed / rendered, etc.

https://www.google.com/search?q=yardbirds+family+tree+-pinterest&hl=en&tbm=isch

title: Fortinet: Govt networks targeted with now-patched SSL-VPN zero-day

last_post.content:
Fortinet says unknown attackers exploited a now-patched FortiOS SSL-VPN zero-day vulnerability in targeted attacks against "governmental or government-related targets."

The company urged customers in mid-December to patch their appliances against ongoing attacks exploiting CVE-2022-42475 after quietly fixing the bug on November 28 (and without revealing that it was a zero-day).

More at https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fortinet-govt-networks-targeted-with-now-patched-ssl-vpn-zero-day/

The Rust base64 crate got a new release the other day, which removed (or rather deprecated for now) the simple encoding/decoding API and requires quite a bit boilerplate for such a simple task.

The maintainer does not see the point in providing a simpler API for the common cases because if the API is too difficult to use then Rust is just the wrong language for you 🙄

Too bad the crate has such a prominent name on crates.io and is used so widely. I hope that doesn't turn away too many beginners because something as simple as base64 handling is so complicated.

The data-encoding crate looks like a good alternative for the same tasks. It provides the same amount of flexibility while still providing a simple API for the common tasks.

https://lib.rs/crates/data-encoding

#rust #RustLang

title: The Unintended Consequences of Test-Based Remediation

last_post.content:
The Unintended Consequences of Test-Based Remediation: NBER Working Paper by David Figlio and Umut Özek.

Students who are sent to remediation receive more educational resources, but are also placed in classes that are more segregated by race, socio-economic status, and prior achievement. In the end, the negative consequences of segregation outweigh the benefits of remedial resources.

https://www.nber.org/papers/w30831

So, you want to style all siblings sitting between a `.upper` and `.lower` element in CSS?

That’s possible … thanks to the almighty `:has()` selector!

```css
.upper ~ :has(~ .lower) {
outline: 1px solid red;
}
```

I'm pretty skeptical of synthetic text detectors like GPTZero (https://etedward-gptzero-main-zqgfwb.streamlit.app/), or OpenAI's own (https://huggingface.co/roberta-base-openai-detector).

For instance, by adding a few "e.g."s or "i.e."s to a generated text, it usually throws GPTZero off enough to label the whole thing as human generated. Also unclear how robust it is to generation parameters (like temperature) or fine-tuned models, given that the detectors themselves are tuned to versioned models.
